posts.name: Anon
posts.cooked:
I really dislike when I want an easy password for myself and signal says ‚Äúsorry that‚Äôs too easy to guess do something else‚Äù and so I get that Signal is trying to be helpful, but sometimes users don‚Äôt need a very hard password. It‚Äôs an inconvenience to me so I‚Äôm like well I guess no password it is. Which is objectively worse from a security standpoint.

Even a password like simple would be better than nothing at all for most people. If someone doubts me, try it yourself. Tell people to guess a password you made up for a hypothetical account. The password will literally just be something stupid easy but no one is going to know that. I‚Äôd bet you no one will think of that, even though it‚Äôs probably the easiest password to guess.

A simple warning that says something along the lines of ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a good idea to have such an easy password are you sure you want to continue?‚Äù would be enough. A good and fair compromise between this everything or nothing approach.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked: You can already set a numeric PIN instead of an alphanumeric password. I think the PIN can be as short as four characters, but it might be six.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
i think OP is referring to the fact Signal currently prevents you from entering an extremely easily guessable PIN:

github.com/signalapp/Signal-Android

app/src/test/resources/data/kbs_pin_validity_vectors.json

ab2f3e791 
[
  {
    "name": "Empty",
    "pin": "",
    "valid": false
  },
  {
    "name": "Alpha",
    "pin": "abcd",
    "valid": true
  },

    "pin": "1234",
    "valid": false
  },
  {
    "name": "Non-sequential",
    "pin": "6485",
    "valid": true
This file has been truncated. show original
The only passwords that Signal prevents are really basic easily guessed things ‚Äì sequential, or all the same, things like 1234, 1111, etc.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked: yeah, you can see in the linked file, all of them are extremely basic. and i doubt too many people will try 1234, get asked to use something slightly better, and give up on the whole thing.
A Signal PIN isn‚Äôt often used (only when changing devices). What is the reason to make it so simple?

posts.name: Anon
posts.cooked:
It saves time, and maybe even more importantly‚Ä¶ Freedom. I just fail to see the logic (if there is any) to where a simple password is deemed to be worse than no password.

If I check signal every few minutes I don‚Äôt like having to put anything complicated in. It adds up over time. So currently its easier to just turn it off. However, there is an inherent risk there.
And while I know someone might think ‚ÄúBut someone could guess an easy password‚Äù
Know what‚Äôs easier to guess? No password. So I just don‚Äôt see the logic here and if there is some way around that, would be great.

Hell, even a pattern lock would be cool. I know that‚Äôs more complicated (for the dev team to program that into signal) so I‚Äôm not even asking since the only thing that has to be done here is literally a few edits to allow whatever pin/password you want.

SignalUser14:

If I check signal every few minutes I don‚Äôt like having to put anything complicated in. It adds up over time.

I think you‚Äôre confusing the Signal PIN with the screen lock, which are separate things. The Signal PIN, which has the complexity requirements that you are taking issue with, is used for account restoration and (optionally) Registration Lock. You only ever need to enter them when you are re-registering Signal, and in the occasional PIN reminder prompt; not every time you use the app.

Because this PIN can be used to hijack your account, it is required to be complex ‚Äì ‚Äúno PIN‚Äù is actually more secure than ‚Äúbad PIN‚Äù because Signal will generate a random key for you in the ‚Äúno PIN‚Äù case. So in a technical sense, you have a PIN, just one that you don‚Äôt know and can‚Äôt use to restore your account. With a bad PIN, someone can guess it and have access to your profile, contacts, and groups.

The screen lock uses your phone‚Äôs screen lock, which has complexity requirements (or not) determined by the OS.

SignalUser14:

If I check signal every few minutes I don‚Äôt like having to put anything complicated in. It adds up over time.

If you are referring to the reminder for the Signal PIN (not your phone screen lock), then you can turn the reminders off in the settings. Then only time you would need your Signal PIN would be when you are reinstalling Signal on the same or different phone, and choose to not use the transfer mechanism nor restore a local backup.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
Herohtar:

and in the occasional PIN reminder prompt

which mind you, can be disabled. so even that is optional.

posts.name: Anon
posts.cooked:
CueHD:

r the Signal PIN (not your phone screen lock), then you can turn the reminders off in the settin

No, not the reminders. I‚Äôm talking about having a pin if you want one. If I had my own freely customizable pin it would be faster than the standards it‚Äôs asking for. That‚Äôs what I mean by time.

I just really don‚Äôt understand why we can‚Äôt have totally customizable passwords/pins.

Also, I know it‚Äôs hard to imagine, but there are people who are barely tech literate. They get locked out of their signal app because they forget their password and we have to just say screw it when we set this up for you again there is just going to be no password. Therefore limit what we talk about with this person on signal and set their disappearing messages to very short. And of course like another thread has asked, specific individual chat passwords being implemented might actually solve most of the issues here.

And I know it might sound like I‚Äôm being petty because this sounds like a minor issue (and I admit it is small compared to other feature requests) I want to say I‚Äôm very grateful and happy with signal as a whole and the features it already has currently.

I‚Äôm only asking because it just seems so easy of a tweak that it could be done by just deleting some code or something since there doesn‚Äôt really seem to be any logical reason to have that as a requirement in order to have a pin/pass.

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
i think you are again confusing two different things. the Signal PIN is only a thing when you switch to another device and don‚Äôt restore from backup. if you don‚Äôt have registration lock enabled (which if someone is ‚Äúbarely tech literate‚Äù i don‚Äôt think they‚Äôll have) then you can just ignore it.
the app lock uses your device‚Äôs password, which if a person doesn‚Äôt know they probably have a bigger problem than just Signal. and that‚Äôs only if a person elects to turn it on.
you seem to be fully misunderstanding the situation where the PIN requirements come up. unless a person regularly switches phones, has registration lock enabled and doesn‚Äôt use backups, the scenario you described just doesn‚Äôt exist.
To be fair, depending on the settings, Signal sometimes nags you to enter your PIN during normal usage as well (to make sure you don‚Äôt forget it), or has this been changed recently?

posts.name: Talya (she/her)
posts.cooked:
you can disable that.

Allow totally customizable passwords? Feature Requests
which mind you, can be disabled. so even that is optional.
CueHD:

you can turn the reminders off in the settings.

and also, nothing happens if you ignore those reminders. Signal doesn‚Äôt lock you out or anything.

rassilon1963:

and also, nothing happens if you ignore those reminders. Signal doesn‚Äôt lock you out or anything.

Yep, and this seems to be what most less tech literate users do if they happened to set a PIN.

There is no issue here; the Signal PIN isn‚Äôt used to lock the app or otherwise secure the chats on the device. The very minimal complexity requirements don‚Äôt even prevent something like 1212 or 1923, which is just as easy to create and remember. Tech literacy doesn‚Äôt have anything to do with the ability to remember a sequence of numbers.

I am all for customization and leaving decisions in the hands of the users, but I do not see the need to change this. The complexity rules are quite permissive. Simply adding ‚ÄúSignal‚Äù to the beginning or end of the simple password in question would be easy enough to pass the complexity check. And has been mentioned, the only time this PIN is used is when migrating to a new phone and not using the built-in methods for transferring one‚Äôs account. If the threat model of a certain user is such that this happens often, then a complex password should be used.

If you need a password that is not the phone screen lock to access Signal every time then you are not using the official Signal client but a fork such as Molly or Signal-JW and should take your feature request to the respective fork author.
